_exec_summary.SummaryText:
C&S Wholesale Grocers' senior management is not only committed to offer superior service, but to also maintain a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding community.  The Corporate Compliance Team assists the facility in administering safety and environmental policies. The Corporate Compliance Team is made up of the following personnel:

¿	Senior Director of Corporate Refrigeration
¿	Corporate Manager of Refrigeration
¿	Senior Manager Environmental Compliance
¿	PSM-RMP Regulatory Manager
¿	Corporate Manager of Facilities Compliance
¿	OSHA Regulatory Manager

The Maintenance Manager periodically evaluates the health and safety practices of facility employees to ensure compliance, and oversees implementation of the safety and environmental programs.  These programs include forklift safety, hazard communications, lockout/tagout, Hazardous Materials Emergency Business Plan, employee safety manuals, manufacturer's documentation, Emergency Response, as well as the Risk Management Plan.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

C&S - Aberdeen is located at 1000 Old Philadelphia Road in Aberdeen, Maryland, which is approximately 1 ½ miles south-east of the I-95.  The area immediately surrounding the facility is rural.
The primary business of C&S - Aberdeen is to provide refrigerated warehousing and storage for various food products.  In order to conduct operations, the facility maintains a refrigeration system containing approximately 52,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia, a regulated substance.  The refrigeration system, consisting of piping, valves, and equipment, cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, and then back to high pressure liquid) in order to provide refrigeration for glycol chilling, dock operations, cold and freezer storage.  Typical operating conditions range from 5 Hg on the low pressure sid

e of the system to 165 psig on the high side of the system.  

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

In order to operate the ammonia refrigeration system, the facility complies with the following risk management regulations:

1)  OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM); and
2)  EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP).

These regulations impose numerous requirements on the facility to ensure the safety of the public and on-site workers.  The following summarizes the key compliance programs that have been implemented by C&S - Aberdeen to prevent the accidental release of ammonia from the facility.  The Operating Procedures program ensures that the ammonia system is operated in a safe manner.  The Training program ensures that personnel fully understand how to perform their jobs in a safe manner.  The Mechanical Integrity program ensures that the ammonia system is in proper working condition based upon routine testing, inspections, and maintenance according to manufacturer's specifications and industry standards.  The Management of Change program ensures that process modifications are implemented in a safe manner.  The Pre-Startup Safety Review program ensures that adequate safety measures are in place before ammonia is introduced into a process.  The Hot Work Permit program ensures that C&S - Aberdeen's employees and contractors perform hot work (e.g. welding) in a safe manner.  The Contractor Safety program ensures that contractors understand the hazards of ammonia and must take specified precautions to safely complete job requirements.

It is important to note that the refrigeration system has been designed with several safety features to prevent the accidental release of ammonia.  For example, the compressors are equipped with safety mechanisms that will cause the units to shut down if operating conditions exceed designated safety limits.  Also, level indicators, alarms, and switches are installed in key points within t

ined for safety hazards by way of a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA).  In addition, three Revalidations of the Process Hazard Analysis have been conducted as follows:

Previous studies have been conducted at the facility as follows [40 CFR 68.67(a)].
¿	Original Study -4/19/199
¿	PHA Revalidation 1 - 11/4/2003
¿	PHA Revalidation 2 - 9/16/2008
¿	PHA Revalidation 3 - 9/9/2013 & 9/10/2013

The PHA Revalidations consisted of:

- Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) study or What-If Studies
- series of safety checklists; and
- facility inspection.

The mitigation measures (recommendations) include additional training, key maintenance-related tests/inspection, and enhanced emergency response policies and procedures.  The recommendations resultant from the most recent revalidation study are scheduled to be addressed by 9/10/2014.

he system to monitor the supply of liquid ammonia and to ensure that a vessel is not overfilled.  The facility has also installed ammonia sensors in the Engine Room which will alert operators in the event of a low-level ammonia detection and cease operation of the refrigeration system in the event of a high-level detection.  There are also ammonia detectors located throughout the freezer warehouse that will alert operators in the event of an ammonia detection in those locations.  An off-site alarm company monitors the ammonia detection system while the facility is unmanned.  In the event of a release while the facility is unmanned, the off-site alarm company will notify the Maintenance Manager and Refrigeration Technicians.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been two reportable releases of ammonia at the facility over the past five years, one in 2012 and one in 2013. Details of these incidents are included in Section 6 of the RMP submittal.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The facility has an Emergency Action Plan (plan) in effect at the facility.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:  

- save lives;
- minimize and avoid injuries;
- protect the environment; and
- minimize property damage.

The Plan provides the notification procedures and evacuation routes for emergencies that may arise at the facility. The Facility is non-responding and has personnel trained to support the HazMat response team if required (up to 300 ppm of ammonia).

There is a specific program (CEHS-0042) which outlines the training, qualifications and procedures for authorized ammonia Incident responders and observers.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations.  Facility personnel receive annual training regarding the emergency procedures and the Emergency Response Team holds regular drills.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

In April 1999, the refrigeration system was thoroughly exam
